message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a congenital heart defect, specifically a ductus-dependent lesion. Prostaglandins E2 can keep the ductus arteriosus open to provide systemic blood flow until surgery can be performed. Indomethacin and low-dose aspirin are not useful in this scenario. Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders in newborns, but it is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn is exhibiting signs of a congenital heart defect called transposition of the great arteries, and prostaglandin E2 can be used to prevent further progression of symptoms by keeping the ductus arteriosus open. Indomethacin and aspirin are not appropriate for this condition, and vitamin K is not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and chest X-ray findings suggest Transposition of the Great Arteries. Prostaglandins E2 enables shunting and recommended for this condition. Indomethacin and Low-dose aspirin are not indicated, while Vitamin K is used for blood clotting disorders, which is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and X-ray findings suggest transposition of the great arteries (TGA), a congenital heart defect where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched. Prostaglandins E2 can help maintain ductal patency and improve pulmonary blood flow, which can prevent further progression of symptoms in a newborn with TGA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and chest X-ray findings suggest that the newborn has a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect commonly seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Prostaglandins E2 can prevent further closure of the PDA and maintain adequate blood flow to the lungs. Indomethacin and low-dose aspirin are used to close an already-open PDA. Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings of a loud S2 and an 'egg-shaped' heart suggest Transposition of the great vessels, which can lead to cyanosis and difficulty breathing. Prostaglandins E2 can help maintain patent ductus arteriosus and maintain blood flow to the lungs. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, Low-dose aspirin is used to reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes, and Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders. None of these medications are relevant to the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible congenital heart defect, such as Ebstein's anomaly or pulmonary atresia. Prostaglandins E2 can be used to keep the ductus arteriosus open and maintain pulmonary blood flow while awaiting corrective surgery. Indomethacin is used to close the ductus arteriosus. Low-dose aspirin is used to prevent blood clots. Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders. None of these medications would prevent further progression of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and chest X-ray findings suggest Transposition of the great vessels, which means the pulmonary artery and aorta are switched. Prostaglandins E2 can help maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus, allowing blood to mix and improve the child's oxygenation. Indomethacin and low-dose aspirin are not indicated in this case. Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders and is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the newborn has a congenital heart defect, specifically a critical duct-dependent systemic circulation. Prostaglandin E2 can help maintain ductal patency and prevent further progression of symptoms. Indomethacin and aspirin are not indicated in this case, and vitamin K is not relevant to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The single loud S2 and 'egg-shaped' heart on chest X-ray suggest a diagnosis of Transposition of the Great Arteries. Prostaglandin E2 is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open and allow for mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, preventing further progression of symptoms. Indomethacin is used to close the ductus arteriosus in cases of patent ductus arteriosus. Low-dose aspirin is used to prevent blood clots. Vitamin K is used to prevent bleeding disorders.
